skill.name: sympy
skill.description: Use this skill when working with symbolic mathematics in Python. This skill should be used for symbolic computation tasks including solving equations algebraically, performing calculus operations (derivatives, integrals, limits), manipulating algebraic expressions, working with matrices symbolically, physics calculations, number theory problems, geometry computations, and generating executable code from mathematical expressions. Apply this skill when the user needs exact symbolic results rather than numerical approximations, or when working with mathematical formulas that contain variables and parameters.

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown files with SymPy guidance and Python code examples. No executable scripts, network calls, file system access, or environment variable usage. The skill provides educational content about using the SymPy library for symbolic mathematics.

content.value_statement: Need exact mathematical results instead of numerical approximations. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for symbolic computation using SymPy including algebra, calculus, matrices, physics, and code generation. Perfect for engineers, scientists, and researchers who need precise symbolic solutions.
actual_capabilities: Solve algebraic, differential, and systems of equations symbolically
Perform calculus operations including derivatives, integrals, limits, and series expansions
Work with matrices symbolically including eigenvalues, determinants, and linear systems
Execute physics calculations for mechanics, quantum mechanics, and vector analysis
Generate executable code from mathematical expressions (Python, C, Fortran, LaTeX)
Perform number theory computations, geometry, and statistics operations
limitations: Requires SymPy library installation in the Python environment
Complex symbolic computations may be slower than numerical alternatives
Some advanced integrations may not have closed-form solutions
Symbolic matrices with symbolic dimensions can become computationally expensive

use_cases.title: Physics problem solving
use_cases.description: Set up and solve mechanics problems, quantum calculations, and vector analysis using symbolic methods.

use_cases.title: Mathematical derivation
use_cases.description: Derive formulas symbolically before converting to numerical code for production pipelines.

use_cases.title: Math learning tool
use_cases.description: Explore mathematical concepts through exact symbolic computation and step-by-step solutions.

prompt_templates.title: Solve equation
prompt_templates.prompt: Solve the equation x squared minus 5x plus 6 equals 0 using SymPy. Show me the step-by-step solution.

prompt_templates.title: Calculate derivative
prompt_templates.prompt: Find the derivative of sin(x) squared with respect to x using SymPy. Then find the second derivative.

prompt_templates.title: Matrix operations
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 3x3 matrix in SymPy and compute its eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and determinant.

prompt_templates.title: Generate code
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert the expression x squared plus 2x plus 1 to a NumPy function using lambdify. Show how to use it with arrays.

output_examples.input: Solve x squared minus 4 equals 0 and find the derivative of x to the power of 3
output: Derivative of x³ with respect to x:
Tip: Use simplify() to verify results and factor() for polynomial factorization.

best_practices: Always define symbols using symbols() before use to avoid NameError
Use Rational() or S() instead of floating-point numbers for exact arithmetic
Apply assumptions to symbols (positive=True, integer=True) to get simpler results
Convert to NumPy functions using lambdify for performance in numerical loops
anti_patterns: Using floating-point numbers like 0.5 instead of Rational(1, 2) for exact results
Calling subs() and evalf() repeatedly in loops instead of using lambdify()
Forgetting to define symbols before using them in expressions
Using subs() at singularities instead of limit() for proper handling

faq.question: What platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. It requires Python with SymPy library installed.

faq.question: How precise are the results?
faq.answer:: SymPy provides exact symbolic results. Use evalf() or N() for numerical approximations with specified precision.

faq.question: Can I integrate with NumPy and SciPy?
faq.answer: Yes. Use lambdify() to convert SymPy expressions to NumPy functions. Works well with SciPy solvers.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill runs locally using the SymPy library. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why is my computation slow?
faq.answer: Complex symbolic operations are computationally expensive. Use numerical methods (lambdify) for large-scale computations.

faq.question: How does this compare to Mathematica or MATLAB?
faq.answer: SymPy provides similar symbolic capabilities for Python. It is free and open-source but may be slower for very complex problems.
